summary: The U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York today entered a final judgment against a former prefect at St. Paul's School, a private coeducational boarding school in Concord, N.H.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in New Hampshire, alleges that on May 30, 2014, the defendant sent an e-mail to a friend with the subject line, "The coming months of slaypril and slay," inviting her to spend time with him. The defendant allegedly told the friend that he wanted to "pork" the victim "more than anyone" and asked her to put in a good word for him. According to the complaint, the friend replied that he "just pulled every trick in the book," including oral sex. The complaint further alleges that the defendant replied, "Praise Jesus, I put on a kind of crush on the victim.” The complaint charges the defendant with violating the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and seeks a permanent injunction, disgorgement of ill-gotten gains with prejudgment interest, and a civil penalty.  In a parallel action, the U.N. Office of Justice and the Federal Bureau of Investigation today announced criminal charges against the defendant. The SEC also issued an order suspending the defendant from appearing or practicing before the SEC as an attorney. The court's order freezes the defendant's assets and prohibits him from participating in any future SEC proceedings. The case is being supervised by Chedly C. Dumornay, Chief of the SEC's Cyber Unit. Â The SEC's Office of Investor Education and Advocacy has issued anÂ Investor AlertÂ to encourage investors to check the background of anyone selling or offering them investments using the free and simple search tool on Investor.gov.Â  The SEC appreciates the assistance of the FBI and the New Hampshire Office of the Attorney General's Office in this matter.
